data.name: Introduction
entries: 这本兽皮书是为讲故事的人和构建世界的人准备的。如果你曾想过为你的朋友们开展龙与地下城游戏，无论是一个晚上的冒险还是一个长期的战役，这本小册子包含了一页又一页的灵感。这是你的一站式商店，可以找到邪恶和良性的生物。

一些居住在D&D世界中的生物起源于现实世界的神话和幻想文学。其他生物则是D&D的原创作品。本书中的怪物是从以前所有版本的游戏中挑选出来的。在这里，你会发现一些经典的小动物，如beholder和displacement beast，还有一些较新的创造，如chuul和twig blight。普通的野兽与怪异的、恐怖的和荒谬的混合在一起。在收集过去的怪物时，我们努力反映出游戏的多面性，包括所有的缺陷。D&D的怪物有各种形状和大小，它们的故事不仅让我们兴奋，也让我们微笑。
如果你是一个有经验的地下城管理员（DM），一些怪物的写法可能会让你吃惊，因为我们已经进入了过去的（%0%），发现了一些久违的事实。我们还增加了一些新的转折点。当然，你可以按照自己的意愿来处理这些怪物。我们在这里所说的一切都不是为了限制你的创造力。如果你的世界里的牛头人是造船师和海盗，我们有什么资格与你争论？毕竟，这是你的世界。

entries.name: How to Use This Book
entries: 做DM的最大好处是，你可以发明你自己的幻想世界，并将其变为现实，而没有什么比居住在D&D世界中的生物更能使其成为现实。你可能会读到一个怪物的条目，然后被刺激到创造一个围绕它的冒险，或者你可能有一个关于地下城的很棒的想法，需要合适的怪物来填充它。这就是《怪物手册》派上用场的地方。
{@i Monster Manual}是构成龙与地下城游戏基础的三本书之一，另外两本书是{@i Player's Handbook}和{@i Dungeon Master's Guide.}
{@i Monster Manual}，和{@i Dungeon Master's Guide}一样，是一本为管理员准备的书。用它来填充你的D&D冒险，包括讨厌的地精、恶臭的troglodytes、野蛮的兽人、强大的龙，以及名副其实的爬行生物。
关于创建怪物遭遇战的指南可以在（%0%）中找到。那本书还包含游荡的怪物表和其他好东西，以帮助你以有趣的方式使用本书中的怪物，以及修改怪物和创造自己的怪物的建议。
如果你以前从未进行过D&D冒险，我们建议你拿起《龙与地下城》{@i Starter Set,}，它演示了如何利用一堆怪物并围绕它们建立一个令人兴奋的冒险。

entries.name: What Is a Monster?
entries: 怪物被定义为任何可以与之互动并有可能被战斗和杀死的生物。根据这个定义，即使是像青蛙一样无害的东西或像独角兽一样仁慈的东西也是怪物。这个术语也适用于人类、精灵、矮人和其他可能成为玩家角色的朋友或对手的文明人。
然而，在D&D世界中出没的大多数怪物都是要被制止的威胁：横行霸道的恶魔、纵容的魔鬼、吸食灵魂的亡灵、被召唤的元素--这样的例子不胜枚举。

entries.name: Where Do Monsters Dwell?
entries: 如果你是D&D游戏的新手，你可能不熟悉那些可以找到并与之战斗的怪异而奇妙的怪物的地方。

entries.name: Dungeons
entries: 当大多数人想到地牢时，脑海中就会浮现出带有铁栅栏和镣铐的黑暗牢房。在D&D游戏中，"地牢 "一词具有更广泛的含义，包括任何封闭的、充满怪物的地方。大多数地牢是庞大的地下建筑群。这里有一些其他的例子。

items: 一座废旧的巫师塔，位于一座孤独的山丘之上，上面布满了妖精出没的隧道。
法老的金字塔充满了闹鬼的地窖和秘密的宝库
丛林中的一座失落的城市，藤蔓丛生，恶魔和崇拜恶魔的邪教徒横行。
由一帮狼人控制的肮脏、迷宫般的下水道系统

entries.name: The Underdark
entries: 没有比地下城更伟大的地牢了，地下城是地表世界下的地下世界。这是一个巨大的地下世界，住着习惯于黑暗的怪物。这个地方充满了无光的洞穴，由蜿蜒向下的隧道连接。人们可以用一生的时间（无论多么短暂！）来探索地下世界，发现以下这些地方。

items: 噬心者的监狱或庇护所，充斥着无意识的傀儡和疯狂的疯子
一个失落的矮人墓地，包含一排又一排尘封的坟墓，等待着被掠夺
坚固的前哨站，满是军备，守卫着通往宏伟的鸦人城市的道路。
充满巨大真菌的地下裂缝，由自大狂或疯狂的福莫里亚国王统治。
在广阔的、没有阳光的海面上有一连串的岩石岛屿，是阿波利斯和疯狂的国土人的家。

entries.name: The Wilderness
entries: 并非所有的怪物都潜伏在地下。他们中的许多人居住在沙漠、山脉、沼泽、峡谷、森林和其他自然环境中。荒野可以和任何地牢一样危险，特别是在无处可藏的情况下！有些荒野的地点和任何地牢一样令人难忘。有些荒野地点和任何地下城一样令人难忘。

items: 用破碎的船体做成的大鹏鸟巢，建在孤独的山峰或岩石山顶上。
广袤的北极苔原，是狂人和雪人的狩猎场。
由树人保护的原始森林或被崇拜恶魔的地精腐蚀的森林
一个被雾气笼罩的沼泽地，被崇拜邪恶黑龙的蜥蜴人所困扰。
一个由恐龙和人类部落战士居住的丛林岛屿

entries.name: Towns and Cities
entries: 一些最好的冒险在文明的摇篮中展开。城市环境为冒险者提供了与富人和权贵擦肩而过的机会，与社会渣滓对峙，剥开文明的外衣，看到潜伏在下面的可怕的邪恶。在中世纪的城镇或城市中，有一些与任何地牢一样致命的地方。

items: 一个钟楼，作为Kenku流氓和刺客公会的基地。
一个隐藏在孤儿院的奴隶窝点，由罗刹人伪装成校长管理。
充斥着腐败和死灵艺术从业者的巫师学院
一个贵族的庄园，富裕的、崇拜魔鬼的邪教徒聚集在这里进行祭祀活动。
寺庙、金库或博物馆，日夜由动画建筑看守。

entries.name: Underwater
entries: 并非所有的冒险都发生在陆地上。本书介绍了萦绕在世界海洋中的几种生物，从邪恶的萨瓦金到厌恶它们的和平水生精灵。在这个水生领域，有许多令人惊讶的冒险地点。

items: 被鲨鱼、水生食尸鬼和愤怒的鬼魂困扰的沉船坟场
风暴巨人的珊瑚城堡，美丽而又不祥的预兆
海底的一座失落的城市，被包裹在一个神奇的气泡中，被一个美杜莎女王所统治
海怪的洞穴或青铜龙的洞穴，充满了古老的宝藏
萨瓦金人的邪恶之神塞科拉（Sekolah）的沉没庙宇

entries.name: The Planes of Existence
entries: 深渊。九层地狱。黄铜之城。这些遥远的地方向高级冒险家们招手，让勇敢的人和愚蠢的人去推翻他们邪恶的主人，揭开他们隐藏的神秘面纱。许多强大、怪异的生物生活在其他存在的星球上，从有序的莫德隆到凶残的恶魔。说到有趣的冒险地点，当你越过世界的边界时，甚至连天空都不是极限。

items: 九层地狱的第一层阿弗纳斯上的一个坑魔据点
影子城的一座闹鬼城堡，作为影子龙的巢穴
翡冷翠的一个精灵女王的坟墓
一个位于空气元素界的精灵宫殿，充满了奇妙的被盗宝物
巫师的秘密半位面，不死的大法师将其法器和法术书藏在那里。

entries: 关于存在平面的更多信息，见{@i Dungeon Master's Guide}。

entries.name: What Monsters to Use?
entries: 许多怪物居住在地下城中，而其他怪物则生活在沙漠、森林、迷宫和其他环境中。无论怪物传统上以哪种环境为家，你都可以把它放在你想放的任何地方。毕竟，"漏网之鱼 "的故事是令人难忘的，而有时让玩家惊讶于藏在沙漠沙地下的砖块或住在地下世界巨大蘑菇中的干尸，也是很有趣的。

entries.name: Modifying Creatures
entries: 尽管本书中收集了大量的怪物，但当你要为冒险的一部分寻找完美的生物时，你可能会感到茫然。你可以自由地调整现有的生物，使其成为对你更有用的东西，也许可以从不同的怪物身上借用一两个特征，或者使用变体或模板，例如本书中的那些。请记住，修改一个怪物，包括当你对它使用模板时，可能会改变它的挑战等级。
关于如何定制生物并计算其挑战等级的建议，请参见{@i Dungeon Master's Guide.}。

entries.name: Statistics
entries: 一个怪物的统计数据，有时被称为它的状态块，提供了你运行该怪物所需要的基本信息。

entries.name: Size
entries: 一个怪物可以是微小的、小的、中等的、大的、巨大的或巨型的。尺寸分类表显示了一个特定尺寸的生物在战斗中控制的空间。关于生物大小和空间的更多信息，请参见6。

entries.name: Type
entries: 一个怪物的类型说明了它的基本性质。游戏中的某些法术、魔法物品、等级特征和其他效果以特殊的方式与特定类型的生物进行互动。例如，屠龙之箭不仅对龙造成额外的伤害，而且对其他龙型生物，如龙龟和狼牙棒，也造成额外的伤害。
该游戏包括以下怪物类型，它们没有自己的规则。
{@b Aberrations}是完全的外星生物。他们中的许多人拥有与生俱来的魔法能力，这些能力来自于生物的异形思维，而不是世界的神秘力量。最典型的反常者是Aboleths、beholder、mind flayers和slaadi。
{@b Beasts}是非人类的生物，是幻想生态的自然组成部分。它们中的一些具有神奇的力量，但大多数是没有智慧的，缺乏任何社会或语言。野兽包括所有品种的普通动物、恐龙和巨型版本的动物。
{@b Celestials}是原产于上层世界的生物。他们中的许多人是神灵的仆人，在凡人界和整个星球上被雇为信使或代理人。天人本性善良，所以偏离善良的特殊天人是一种可怕的罕见现象。天人包括天使、库阿特人和佩加西人。
{@b Constructs}是制造出来的，而不是天生的。有些是由创造者编程，遵循一套简单的指令，而有些则被赋予了智慧，能够进行独立思考。盔甲是标志性的建筑。许多土生土长的麦金努斯星球的生物，比如莫德隆，都是由更强大的生物的意志从星球的原材料中塑造出来的构造体。
{@b Dragons}是起源古老、力量巨大的大型爬行生物。真龙，包括善良的金属龙和邪恶的色龙，具有高度的智慧和天生的魔法。这一类中还有与真龙有远距离关系的生物，但力量、智慧和魔法都较弱，如狼人和假龙。
{@b Elementals}是原产于元素界的生物。这种类型的一些生物只不过是其各自元素的有生命的物质，包括简单地称为元素的生物。其他的则是注入了元素能量的生物形态。精灵的种族，包括精灵和伊夫雷特，形成了元素界最重要的文明。其他元素生物包括阿泽尔、隐形潜行者和水鸟。
{@b Fey}是与自然力量紧密相连的神奇生物。他们居住在黄昏的树林和缥缈的森林中。在一些世界中，他们与精灵世界（Feywild）紧密相连，也被称为精灵界。有些也被发现于外部世界，特别是阿波瑞亚（Arborea）和兽地（Beastlands）的平面。妖精包括干尸、小精灵和萨提尔。
{@b Fiends}是原产于下层世界的邪恶的生物。少数是神明的仆人，但更多的是在大恶魔和恶魔王子的领导下工作。邪恶的牧师和法师有时会将恶魔召唤到物质世界来为他们效劳。如果说邪恶的天人是罕见的，那么好的魔人则几乎是不可想象的。魔鬼包括恶魔、魔鬼、地狱猎犬、罗刹和尤格罗特。
{@b Giants}高过人类和他们的同类。他们的形状类似于人类，尽管有些人有多个头（ETTINS）或畸形（FOMORIAN）。真正的巨人有六种，分别是山丘巨人、石头巨人、冰霜巨人、火焰巨人、云雾巨人和风暴巨人。除了这些，食人魔和巨魔等生物也是巨人。
{@b Humanoids}是D&D世界的主要民族，既有文明的也有野蛮的，包括人类和种类繁多的其他物种。他们有语言和文化，几乎没有先天的魔法能力（尽管大多数人形生物可以学习法术），并且是两足动物的形态。最常见的类人种族是最适合作为玩家角色的种族：人类、矮人、精灵和半身人。几乎同样多但更野蛮、更凶残，而且几乎一致邪恶的种族是地精（地精、霍布格林和虫熊）、兽人、地精、蜥蜴人和哥布林。
本书中出现了各种人形生物，但{@i Player's Handbook}中详述的种族--除了乌鸦之外--都在附录B中处理。该附录给了你一些状态块，你可以用来制造这些种族的各种成员。
{@b Monstrosities}是最严格意义上的怪物--可怕的生物，它们不是普通的，不是真正的自然，而且几乎没有良性的。有些是魔法实验出错的结果（如猫头鹰熊），有些是可怕的诅咒的产物（包括牛头人和元神）。它们无法归类，在某种意义上说，它们是不适合任何其他类型的生物的总括性类别。
{@b Oozes}是胶状的生物，很少有固定的形状。它们大多在地下，居住在山洞和地牢中，以垃圾、腐肉或不幸挡住它们去路的生物为食。黑色的布丁和胶状的方块是最容易识别的渗出物之一。
{@b Plants}在这里指的是植物性生物，而不是普通的植物群。它们中的大多数是流动的，有些是食肉的。最典型的植物是晃动的小丘和树人。真菌类生物，如气体孢子和霉菌类也属于这一类别。
{@b Undead}是曾经活着的生物，通过使用死灵魔法或一些邪恶的诅咒，被带到了可怕的不死状态。亡灵包括行尸走肉，如吸血鬼和僵尸，以及无体的精神，如鬼魂和幽灵。

entries.name: Tags
entries: 一个怪物可能有一个或多个标签附加在它的类型上，放在括号里。例如，兽人有（%0%）类型。括号内的标签为某些生物提供了额外的分类。这些标签没有自己的规则，但游戏中的某些东西，如魔法物品，可能会提到它们。例如，一支对打击恶魔特别有效的长矛会对任何有恶魔标签的怪物有效。

entries.name: Alignment
entries: 怪物的排列组合提供了一条线索，说明它的性格以及它在角色扮演或战斗中的行为方式。例如，混沌邪恶的怪物可能很难与之讲道理，并可能一见面就攻击角色，而中立的怪物则可能愿意进行谈判。请参阅{@i Player's Handbook}中对不同结盟的描述。
在怪物的状态块中指定的排列方式是默认的。你可以自由地偏离它，改变怪物的排列，以适应你的活动的需要。如果你想要一个善良的绿龙或邪恶的风暴巨人，没有什么可以阻止你。有些生物可以有任何对齐方式。换句话说，你可以选择怪物的对齐方式。有些怪物的对准条目表示对法律、混乱、善或恶的倾向或厌恶。例如，一个狂暴战士可以是任何混乱的对准（混乱的好，混乱的中立，或混乱的邪恶），这与它的野性相称。
许多智力低下的生物对法律或混乱、善或恶没有理解力。他们不做道德或伦理上的选择，而是凭本能行事。这些生物是不结盟的，这意味着他们没有一个结盟。

entries.name: Armor Class
entries: 穿着盔甲或带着盾牌的怪物有一个考虑到其盔甲、盾牌和灵巧性的护甲等级（AC）。否则，怪物的护甲等级是基于它的灵巧修正值和自然护甲（如果有的话）。如果一个怪物有天然护甲，穿戴护甲，或携带盾牌，这将在其AC值后面的括号中注明。

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: 当一个怪物的命中率下降到0时，它通常会死亡或被消灭。更多关于命中率的信息，请参见{@i Player's Handbook.}。
一个怪物的命中率既可以用模子表达，也可以用平均数来表示。例如，一个拥有{@dice 2d8}命中率的怪物平均有9个命中率（2×4½）。
怪物的大小决定了用于计算其命中率的骰子，如按大小计算的命中率表所示。
一个怪物的体质修正值也会影响它的命中率。它的体质修正值乘以它所拥有的命中率点数，然后将结果加到它的命中率上。例如，如果一个怪物的体质是12（+1修改器），命中率是（%0%），它就有（%1%）的命中率（平均11）。

entries.name: Speed
entries: 一个怪物的速度告诉你它在其回合中能移动多远。关于速度的更多信息，请参见{@i Player's Handbook.}。
所有的生物都有一个行走速度，简单地说就是怪物的速度。没有地面运动形式的生物，其行走速度为0英尺。
有些生物具有以下一种或多种额外的运动模式。

entries.name: Burrow
entries: 拥有钻洞速度的怪物可以使用该速度在沙子、泥土、泥浆或冰中移动。怪物不能钻过坚硬的岩石，除非它有一个特殊的特性允许它这样做。

entries.name: Climb
entries: 拥有攀爬速度的怪物可以使用其全部或部分移动来在垂直表面上移动。该怪物不需要花费额外的移动来攀爬。

entries.name: Fly
entries: 拥有飞行速度的怪物可以使用其全部或部分移动来飞行。有些怪物具有盘旋的能力，这使得它们很难被击落在空中（如{@i Player's Handbook}中关于飞行的规则所解释）。这样的怪物在死亡时就会停止盘旋。

entries.name: Swim
entries: 一个拥有游泳速度的怪物不需要花费额外的移动来游泳。

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: 每个怪物都有六个能力分数（力量、灵巧、体质、智力、智慧和魅力）和相应的修改器。关于能力分数的更多信息以及它们在游戏中的使用方法，请参见{@i Player's Handbook.}。

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: 蓄力投掷条目是为那些善于抵御某些类型的效果的生物保留的。例如，一个不容易受到{@condition charmed}或{@condition frightened}影响的生物可能会在其智慧蓄力上获得奖励。大多数生物都没有特殊的蓄力攻击奖励，在这种情况下，这一部分就没有了。
救赎奖励是怪物的相关能力修改值和熟练度奖励的总和，熟练度奖励由怪物的挑战等级决定（如挑战等级的熟练度奖励表所示）。

entries.name: Skills
entries: 技能项是为精通一种或多种技能的怪物保留的。例如，一个非常敏锐和隐蔽的怪物可能对智慧（{@skill Perception}）和灵巧（{@skill Stealth}）检查有奖励。
技能奖励是怪物的相关能力修饰和熟练度奖励的总和，熟练度奖励由怪物的挑战等级决定（如挑战等级的熟练度奖励表所示）。其他的修改器可能适用。例如，一个怪物可能会有一个比预期更大的奖励（通常是其熟练度奖励的两倍），以说明其高度的专业性。

entries.name: Vulnerabilities, Resistances, and Immunities
entries: 有些生物对某些类型的伤害具有脆弱性、抵抗性或免疫性。某些生物甚至对非魔法攻击的伤害有抵抗力或免疫力（魔法攻击是指由法术、魔法物品或其他魔法来源发出的攻击）。此外，有些生物对某些情况是免疫的。

entries.name: Senses
entries: 感官条目记录了一个怪物的被动智慧（（%0%））得分，以及怪物可能拥有的任何特殊感官。特殊感官的描述见下文。

entries.name: Blindsight
entries: 一个拥有（%0%）的怪物可以在特定的半径范围内不依靠视觉来感知它的周围环境。没有眼睛的生物，例如狰狞的人和灰白的人，通常都有这种特殊的感觉，具有回声定位或高度感觉的生物也一样，例如蝙蝠和真龙。
如果一个怪物是自然盲目的，它就会有一个这样的括号，表明它的（%0%）半径定义了它的感知的最大范围。

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: 拥有{@sense darkvision}的怪物可以在特定半径内的黑暗中看到。该怪物可以在半径范围内看到昏暗的光线，就像看到亮光一样，在黑暗中看到昏暗的光线。该怪物在黑暗中不能辨别颜色，只能辨别灰色的深浅。许多生活在地下的生物都有这种特殊的感觉。

entries.name: Tremorsense
entries: 拥有{@sense tremorsense|MM}的怪物可以探测并确定特定范围内振动的来源，前提是怪物和振动的来源接触到相同的地面或物质。震颤感应不能用于探测飞行或无体生物。许多钻地的生物，比如安克希斯和乌尔克，都有这种特殊感应。

entries.name: Truesight
entries: 拥有{@sense truesight}的怪物可以在特定范围内看到普通和魔法黑暗，看到{@condition invisible}的生物和物体，自动检测视觉错觉，并成功抵御它们，感知变身者或被魔法转化的生物的原始形态。此外，在相同的范围内，该怪物可以看到虚空界。

entries.name: Languages
entries: 怪物能说的语言是按字母顺序排列的。有时，一个怪物能听懂一种语言，但不能说，这将在其条目中注明。"-"表示一个怪物既不说也不懂任何语言。

entries.name: Telepathy
entries: 心灵感应是一种神奇的能力，它允许一个怪物在指定范围内与另一个生物进行精神交流。被联系的生物不需要与怪物共享一种语言就能以这种方式与它交流，但它必须能够理解至少一种语言。没有心灵感应的生物可以接收和回应心灵感应的信息，但不能启动或终止心灵感应的对话。
心灵感应的怪物不需要看到被联系的生物，并且可以在任何时候结束心灵感应的联系。一旦两个生物不再在彼此的范围内，或者心灵感应的怪物在范围内接触到一个不同的生物，接触就会中断。心灵感应的怪物可以发起或终止心灵感应的对话，而不需要使用行动，但是当怪物处于（%0%）时，它不能发起心灵感应的接触，任何当前的接触都会被终止。
在反魔法场的范围内或在任何其他魔法不起作用的地方，生物不能发送或接收心灵感应的信息。

entries.name: Armor, Weapon, and Tool Proficiencies
entries: 假设一个生物精通其盔甲、武器和工具。如果你把它们换掉，你决定该生物是否精通其新装备。
例如，一个山丘巨人通常穿着皮甲，挥舞着大棒。你可以为山丘巨人装备链甲和大斧，并假设巨人同时精通这两种武器，或其中一种，或两种都不精通。
关于不熟练使用盔甲或武器的规则，见{@i Player's Handbook}。

entries.name: Challenge
entries: 一个怪物的挑战等级告诉你这个怪物的威胁有多大。一个装备精良、休息良好的四人冒险团应该能够击败挑战等级与其等级相当的怪物，而不会有任何死亡。例如，一个由四个三级角色组成的队伍应该发现挑战等级为3的怪物是一个值得挑战的东西，但不是一个致命的东西。
显著弱于1级角色的怪物的挑战等级低于1。
挑战等级为0的怪物，除了数量多以外，都是无足轻重的；没有有效攻击的怪物不值任何经验值，而有攻击的怪物，每只值10XP。
有些怪物带来的挑战甚至超过了一个典型的20级队伍所能应付的程度。这些怪物的挑战等级为21级或更高，是专门用来测试玩家技能的。

entries.name: Experience Points
entries: 怪物的经验值（XP）是基于其挑战等级。通常情况下，击败怪物就可以获得XP，尽管DM也可以通过其他方式消除怪物造成的威胁而获得XP。
除非有其他东西告诉你，由法术或其他魔法能力召唤的怪物值得在其状态块中注明XP。
{@i Dungeon Master's Guide}解释了如何使用XP预算创建遭遇战，以及如何调整遭遇战的难度。

entries.name: Special Traits
entries: 特殊特征（出现在怪物的挑战等级之后，但在任何行动或反应之前）是在战斗遭遇中可能相关的特征，需要一些解释。

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: A monster with the innate ability to cast spells has the Innate Spellcasting special trait. Unless noted otherwise. an innate spell of 1st level or higher is always cast at its lowest possible level and can't be cast at a higher level. If a monster has a cantrip where its level matters and no level is given, use the monster's challenge rating.

An innate spell can have special rules or restrictions. For example, a drow mage can innately cast the {@spell levitate} spell, but the spell has a "self only" restriction, which means that the spell affects only the drow mage.
A monster's innate spells can't be swapped out with other spells. If a monster's innate spells don't require attack rolls, no attack bonus is given for them.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: A monster with the Spellcasting special trait has a spellcaster level and spell slots, which it uses to cast its spells of 1st level and higher (as explained in the {@i Player's Handbook}). The spellcaster level is also used for any cantrips included in the feature.

The monster has a list of spells known or prepared from a specific class. The list might also include spells from a feature in that class, such as the Divine Domain feature of the cleric or the Druid Circle feature of the druid. The monster is considered a member of that class when attuning to or using a magic item that requires membership in the class or access to its spell list.

A monster can cast a spell from its list at a higher level if it has the spell slot to do so. For example, a drow mage with the 3rd level {@spell lightning bolt} spell can cast it as a 5th-level spell by using one of its 5th-level spell slots.

You can change the spells that a monster knows or has prepared, replacing any spell on its spell list with a spell of the same level and from the same class list. If you do so. you might cause the monster to be a greater or lesser threat than suggested by its challenge rating.

entries.name: Psionics
entries: A monster that casts spells using only the power of its mind has the psionics tag added to its Spellcasting or Innate Spellcasting special trait. This tag carries no special rules of its own, but other parts of the game might refer to it. A monster that has this tag typically doesn't require any components to cast its spells.

entries.name: Actions
entries: When a monster takes its action, it can choose from the options in the Actions section of its stat block or use one of the actions available to all creatures, such as the {@action Dash} or {@action Hide} action, as described in the {@i Player's Handbook.}

entries.name: Melee and Ranged Attacks
entries: The most common actions that a monster will take in combat are melee and ranged attacks. These can be spell attacks or weapon attacks, where the "weapon" might be a manufactured item or a natural weapon, such as a claw or tail spike. For more information on different kinds of attacks, see the {@i Player's Handbook.}

entries.name: Creature vs. Target
entries: The target of a melee or ranged attack is usually either one creature or one target, the difference being that a "target" can be a creature or an object.

entries.name: Hit
entries: Any damage dealt or other effects that occur as a result of an attack hitting a target are described after the "Hit" notation. You have the option of taking average damage or rolling the damage; for this reason, both the average damage and the die expression are presented.

entries.name: Miss
entries: If an attack has an effect that occurs on a miss, that information is presented after the "Miss:" notation.

entries.name: Multiattack
entries: A creature that can make multiple attacks on its turn has the Multiattack ability. A creature can't use Multiattack when making an opportunity attack, which must be a single melee attack.

entries.name: Ammunition
entries: A monster carries enough ammunition to make its ranged attacks. You can assume that a monster has {@dice 2d4} pieces of ammunition for a thrown weapon attack, and {@dice 2d10} pieces of ammunition for a projectile weapon such as a bow or crossbow.

entries.name: Reactions
entries: If a monster can do something special with its reaction, that information is contained here. If a creature has no special reaction, this section is absent.

entries.name: Limited Usage
entries: Some special abilities have restrictions on the number of times they can be used.

entries.name: X/Day
entries: The notation "X/Day" means a special ability can be used X number of times and that a monster must finish a long rest to regain expended uses. For example, "1/Day" means a special ability can be used once and that the monster must finish a long rest to use it again.

entries.name: Recharge X-Y
entries: The notation "Recharge X-Y" means a monster can use a special ability once and that the ability then has a random chance of recharging during each subsequent round of combat. At the start of each of the monster's turns, roll a {@dice d6}. If the roll is one of the numbers in the recharge notation, the monster regains the use of the special ability. The ability also recharges when the monster finishes a short or long rest. For example, "Recharge 5-6" means a monster can use the special ability once. Then, at the start of the monster's turn, it regains the use of that ability if it rolls a 5 or 6 on a {@dice d6}.

entries.name: Recharge after a Short or Long Rest
entries: This notation means that a monster can use a special ability once and then must finish a short or long rest to use it again.

entries.name: Grapple Rules for Monsters
entries: Many monsters have special attacks that allow them to quickly grapple prey. When a monster hits with such an attack, it doesn't need to make an additional ability check to determine whether the grapple succeeds, unless the attack says otherwise.

A creature {@condition grappled} by the monster can use its action to try to escape. To do so, it must succeed on a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check against the escape DC in the monster's stat block. If no escape DC is given, assume the DC is 10 + the monster's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) modifier.

entries.name: Equipment
entries: A stat block rarely refers to equipment, other than armor or weapons used by a monster. A creature that customarily wears clothes, such as a humanoid, is assumed to be dressed appropriately.

You can equip monsters with additional gear and trinkets however you like, using the equipment chapter of the {@i Player's Handbook} for inspiration, and you decide how much of a monster's equipment is recoverable after the creature is slain and whether any of that equipment is still usable. A battered suit of armor made for a monster is rarely usable by someone else, for instance.
If a spellcasting monster needs material components to cast its spells, assume that it has the material components it needs to cast the spells in its stat block.

entries.name: Legendary Creatures
entries: A legendary creature can do things that ordinary creatures can't. Legendary creatures can take special actions outside their turns, and a few can exert power over their environment, causing extraordinary magical effects to occur in their vicinity.
If a creature assumes the form of a legendary creature, such as through a spell, it doesn't gain that form's legendary actions, lair actions, or regional effects.

entries.name: Legendary Actions
entries: A legendary creature can take a certain number of special actions-called legendary actions-outside its turn. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. A legendary creature regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn. It can forgo using them, and it can't use them while {@condition incapacitated} or otherwise unable to take actions. If {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised}, it can't use them until after its first turn in the combat.

entries.name: A Legendary Creature's Lair
entries: A legendary creature might have a section describing its lair and the special effects it can create while there, either by act of will or simply by being present. Not all legendary creatures have lairs. This section only applies to legendary creatures that spend a great deal of time in their lairs and are most likely to be encountered there.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: If a legendary creature has lair actions, it can use them to harness the ambient magic in its lair. On initiative count 20 (losing all initiative ties), it can use one of its lair action options. It can't do so while {@condition incapacitated} or otherwise unable to take actions. If {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised}, it can't use one until after its first turn in the combat.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The mere presence of a legendary creature can have strange and wondrous effects on its environment, as noted in this section. Regional effects end abruptly or dissipate over time when the legendary creature dies.

entries.name: Shadow Dragon Template
entries: Only a true dragon can transform into a shadow dragon, and only if it is born in the Shadowfell or remains there for several years. A dracolich can't be turned into a shadow dragon, since it loses its draconic nature when it becomes undead.

When a dragon becomes a shadow dragon, it retains its statistics except as described below. The shadow dragon might retain or lose any or all of its lair actions or inherit new ones, as the DM sees fit.

entries.name: Damage Resistances
entries: The dragon has resistance to necrotic damage.

entries.name: Skill Proficiency: Stealth
entries: The dragon's proficiency bonus is doubled for its Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

entries.name: Living Shadow
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the dragon has resistance to damage that isn't force, psychic, or radiant.

entries.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the dragon can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action.

entries.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the dragon has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

entries.name: New Action: Bite
entries: If the dragon deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage with its bite, change that damage type to necrotic.

entries.name: New Action: Shadow Breath
entries: Any damage-dealing breath weapon possessed by the dragon deals necrotic damage instead of its original damage type. A humanoid reduced to 0 hit points by this damage dies, and an undead shadow rises from its corpse and acts immediately after the dragon in the initiative count. The shadow is under the dragon's control.

entries.name: Half-Dragon Template
entries: A beast, humanoid, giant, or monstrosity can become a half-dragon. When a creature becomes a half-dragon, it retains all its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: Challenge
entries: To avoid recalculating the creature's challenge rating, apply the template only to a creature that meets the optional prerequisite in the Breath Weapon table below. Otherwise, use the guidelines in the Dungeon Master's Guide to recalculate the rating after you apply the template.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The half-dragon gains {@sense blindsight} with a radius of 10 feet and {@sense darkvision} with a radius of 60 feet.

entries.name: Resistances
entries: The half-dragon gains resistance to a type of damage based on its color.

entries.name: Languages
entries: The half-dragon speaks Draconic in addition to any other languages it knows.

entries.name: New Action: Breath Weapon
entries: The half-dragon has the breath weapon of its dragon half. The half-dragon's size determines how this action functions.

entries.name: Spore Servant Template
entries: A spore servant is any Large or smaller creature brought back to life by the animating spores of a myconid sovereign. A creature that was never flesh and blood to begin with (such as a construct, elemental, ooze, plant, or undead) can't be turned into a spore servant. The following characteristics change or are added to a creature that becomes a spore servant.

entries.name: Retained Characteristics
entries: The servant retains its Armor Class, hit points, Hit Dice, Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, vulnerabilities, resistances, and immunities.

entries.name: Lost Characteristics
entries: The servant loses its original saving throw and skill bonuses, special senses, and special traits. It loses any action that isn't Multiattack or a melee weapon attack that deals bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. If it has an action or a melee weapon attack that deals some other type of damage, it loses the ability to deal damage of that type, unless the damage comes from a piece of equipment, such as a magic item.

entries.name: Type
entries: The servant's type is plant, and it loses any tags.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The servant is unaligned.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Reduce all the servant's speeds by 10 feet, to a minimum of 5 feet.

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: The servant's ability scores change as follows: Int 2 (−4), Wis 6 (−2), Cha 1 (−5).

entries.name: Senses
entries: The servant has {@sense blindsight} with a radius of 30 feet, and it is blind beyond this radius.

entries.name: Condition Immunities
entries: The servant can't be {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, or {@condition paralyzed}.

entries.name: Languages
entries: The servant loses all known languages, but it responds to orders given to it by myconids using rapport spores. The servant gives highest priority to orders received from the most powerful myconid.

entries.name: Attacks
entries: If the servant has no other means of dealing damage, it can use its fists or limbs to make unarmed strikes. On a hit, an unarmed strike deals bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d4} + the servant's Strength modifier, or, if the servant is Large, {@dice 2d4} + its Strength modifier.

data.name: Appendix A: Miscellaneous Creatures
entries: This appendix contains statistics for various animals, vermin, and other critters. The stat blocks are organized alphabetically by creature name.

entries.name: Other Animals
entries: A book of this size can't contain statistics for every animal inhabiting your D&D campaign world. However, you can use the stat block of one animal to represent another easily enough. For example, you can use the panther statistics to represent a jaguar, the giant goat statistics to represent a buffalo, and the hawk statistics to represent a falcon.

data.name: Appendix B: Nonplayer Characters
entries: This appendix contains statistics for various humanoid nonplayer characters (NPCs) that adventurers might encounter during a D&D campaign, including lowly commoners and mighty archmages. These stat blocks can be used to represent both human and nonhuman NPCs.
There are many easy ways to customize the NPCs in this appendix for your home campaign.

entries.name: Racial Traits
entries: You can add racial traits to an NPC. For example, a halfling druid might have a speed of 25 feet and the Lucky trait. Adding racial traits to an NPC doesn't alter its challenge rating. For more on racial traits, see the Player's Handbook.

entries.name: Spell Swaps
entries: One way to customize an NPC spellcaster is to replace one or more of its spells. You can substitute any spell on the NPC's spell list with a different spell of the same level from the same spell list. Swapping spells in this manner doesn't alter an NPC's challenge rating.

entries.name: Armor and Weapon Swaps
entries: You can upgrade or downgrade an NPC's armor, or add or switch weapons. Adjustments to Armor Class and damage can change an NPC's challenge rating, as explained in the Dungeon Master's Guide.

entries.name: Magic Items
entries: The more powerful an NPC, the more likely it has one or more magic items in its possession. An archmage, for example, might have a magic staff or wand, as well as one or more potions and scrolls. Giving an NPC a potent damage-dealing magic item could alter its challenge rating. Magic items, as well as adjusting a creature's challenge rating, are described in the Dungeon Master's Guide.
